text: this is a heart attack a fatty deposit
or plaque has ruptured blocking the
supply of blood to the artery above it
starving it of oxygen researchers think
they've discovered a way of detecting
these dangerous plaques in advance they
found that by injecting patients with a
radioactive tracer and then using one of
these high-resolution scanners they
could light up images of the areas at
risk in tests on 40 people who'd had a
heart attack the scan highlighted the
plaque that had caused the problem in 37
patients but the authors say more
research is needed and it will be at
least another five to ten years before
this approach is used routinely to
identify patients at risk of a future
heart attack okay so we look at this
scan there so if we show that this
really does predict heart attacks then
you know then we're in business then we
can really look to finding these
individuals at high risk and giving them
the treatment that would hopefully
prevent heart attacks from Canada the
British Heart Foundation which part
funded the study said this technique may
identify what it calls ticking time-bomb
patients at risk of a heart attack
something other tests can't do adam brim
ello BBC news
